clinical examiniation in males: all male animals dosed with 681 mg/kg bw survived the 14-day observation period. all males survived a treatment of 1470 mg/kg bw. clinical signs included dyspnoea, apathy, abnormal posture, staggering, atony, deficiency in pain and cornea reflex, coma-like state, spastic gait, rough fur, exsiccosis, exophthalmoses, and general poor condition.
clinical examiniation in females: all female animals dosed with 681 mg/kg bw survived the 14-day observation period.  clinical signs included dyspnoea, apathy, abnormal posture, staggering, atony, deficiency in pain and cornea reflex, coma-like state, spastic gait, rough fur, exsiccosis, exophthalmoses, and general poor condition. generally females were more susceptible to 2- phenoxyethanol than males.
gross pathology in females: animals that died during the study course revealed the following signs at necropsy: hyperaemic congestion; lungs which were slightly inflated; sporadically reddened glandular stomach.
mortality rate in males: in all treatment groups, the latest time point where death occurred was observation day 1. at a dose level of 3160 mg/kg bw, 2 males died. at the highest dose level 3 males died.
mortality rate in females: in all treatment groups, the latest time point where death occurred was observation day 1. 2 out of 5 female rats died at 1470 mg/kg bw, at a dose level of 3160 mg/kg bw, 4 females died. at the highest dose level all females died.
SCCS comment to test: although this study was not conducted under glp and the concentration of the test substance was reported as ca. 80%, the study is considered sufficiently reliable for evaluation of the endpoint of acute oral toxicity.
additional information: two other acute oral toxicity studies in rats and rabbits, which dated from 1980 and were poorly documented, resulted in LD-50 values of 1- 2 g/kg bw.

clinical examiniation in males: the animals were checked daily for mortality and clinical signs. body weights were recorded on days 1 to 5, 7, 8, 11 and 15. liver changes associated with the test substance were observed at 4149 mg/kg bw in mice and at 9641 mg/kg bw in rats, though not at lower dosage levels. few toxic signs were observed in either species at dosage levels up to 3513 mg/kg bw.
clinical examiniation in females: the animals were checked daily for mortality and clinical signs. body weights were recorded on days 1 to 5, 7, 8, 11 and 15. liver changes associated with the test substance were observed at 4149 mg/kg bw in mice and at 9641 mg/kg bw in rats, though not at lower dosage levels. few toxic signs were observed in either species at dosage levels up to 3513 mg/kg bw.
mortality rate in females: in rats at 1792 (mg/kg bw) :0/5, 2509 (mg/kg bw) :0/5, 3513 (mg/kg bw): 0/5, 4919 (mg/kg bw): 0/5, 6886 (mg/kg bw): 1/5, 9641 (mg/kg bw): 3/5, 13496 (mg/kg bw): 4/5, 18895 (mg/kg bw): 5/5; in mice 1792 (mg/kg bw) :0/5, 2509 (mg/kg bw) :0/5, 3513 (mg/kg bw): 0/5, 4919 (mg/kg bw): 0/5, 6886 (mg/kg bw): * 1/4, 9641 (mg/kg bw): 3/5, 13496 (mg/kg bw): 3/5, 18895 (mg/kg bw): 5/5. * one of the five 6886 mg/kg bw female mice died by gavage accident
conclusion: low level of acute oral toxicity in both rat and mouse

clinical examiniation in males: animals were observed at least daily for clinical signs and twice daily for mortality. body weights were recorded on day 1 just before treatment and on days 5 and 8. animals found dead or killed prematurely and all surviving animals killed at the end of the study were subjected to macroscopic examination. organs showing gross anomalies were sampled and preserved, but no histopathological examination was performed. neither mortality nor clinical signs were observed during the study.
microscopic pathology in males: microscopic examination of the main organs of the animals revealed no apparent abnormalities.
clinical examiniation in females: animals were observed at least daily for clinical signs and twice daily for mortality. body weights were recorded on day 1 just before treatment and on days 5 and 8. animals found dead or killed prematurely and all surviving animals killed at the end of the study were subjected to macroscopic examination. organs showing gross anomalies were sampled and preserved, but no histopathological examination was performed. neither mortality nor clinical signs were observed during the study.
microscopic pathology in females: microscopic examination of the main organs of the animals revealed no apparent abnormalities.
conclusion: under the conditions of this study, no clinical signs and no deaths were observed after a single oral administration of methylimidazoliumpropyl p-phenylenediamine, Cl, 2HCl (A166) at the dose level of 500 mg/kg in rats.
SCCS comment to test: animals were observed until day 8 instead of for 14 days, but since no mortality was registered, it can be deduced that the oral LD50 is higher than 500 mg/kg b.w

clinical examiniation in males: during the observation period of 14 days, a record was kept for mortalities and signs of toxicity. body weights were recorded on day 0 and day 14 for the surviving animals. all rats that died were investigated macroscopically to identify organ changes in the skull, thorax and abdomen and surviving animals were similarly examined at the end of the 14- day post-observation.
clinical examiniation in females: during the observation period of 14 days, a record was kept for mortalities and signs of toxicity. body weights were recorded on day 0 and day 14 for the surviving animals. all rats that died were investigated macroscopically to identify organ changes in the skull, thorax and abdomen and surviving animals were similarly examined at the end of the 14- day post-observation.
conclusion: no mortalities occurred at the dose of 5 g/kg bw. yellow colorations of the skin and mucosae were observed until the fourth day after administration of the tested dose. no other signs of reaction to treatment were observed.
preliminary study: hc yellow n°4 was prepared as a 50 % suspension in distilled water and administered by oral intubation at the doses of 1, 2.5 and 5 g/kg bw in range finding test (2 males per dose). as no mortalities occurred at these doses, 5 g/kg bw was chosen for the primary test (5 males and 5 females).

clinical examiniation in males: behaviour, reactions and physical signs of the animals were observed and findings were recorded at 1, 10, 30 min, 1, 2, 4 and 6 hours post administration and then at least once a day for 2 weeks. body weight was determined before administration, and 7 and 14 days post administration. any found dead animal was dissected and submitted to a macroscopic post-mortem examination in order to identify the target organs. all surviving animals were sacrificed by CO2 asphyxation at 14 days post administration and examined macroscopically. no effects on body weight and body weight gain were observed. all animals showed signs of malaise (e.g. decreased motor activity, ruffled fur, closed eyes, hunched posture, decreased muscular tension or unconsciousness). in some animals ataxia, dyspnoea or low grade convulsions were observed. fffects diminished and returned to normal within 6hr – 1wk post administration.
gross pathology in males: 7/20 of the animals that died early did not show any clinical signs at the post-mortem examination. most of the other animals that died early showed signs of shock due to severe gastrointestinal irritations or hepatotoxicity
clinical examiniation in females: behaviour, reactions and physical signs of the animals were observed and findings were recorded at 1, 10, 30 min, 1, 2, 4 and 6 hours post administration and then at least once a day for 2 weeks. body weight was determined before administration, and 7 and 14 days post administration. any found dead animal was dissected and submitted to a macroscopic post-mortem examination in order to identify the target organs. all surviving animals were sacrificed by CO2 asphyxation at 14 days post administration and examined macroscopically. no effects on body weight and body weight gain were observed. all animals showed signs of malaise (e.g. decreased motor activity, ruffled fur, closed eyes, hunched posture, decreased muscular tension or unconsciousness). in some animals ataxia, dyspnoea or low grade convulsions were observed. fffects diminished and returned to normal within 6hr – 1wk post administration.
gross pathology in females: 7/20 of the animals that died early did not show any clinical signs at the post-mortem examination. most of the other animals that died early showed signs of shock due to severe gastrointestinal irritations or hepatotoxicity
mortality rate in males: all dead in the 112 or 200mg/kg bw. death occurred between 1 hr-4 days in the 112 mg/kg bw group and between 30 min-2 hr in the 200 mg/kg bw group. 1/10 of the animals in the 63 mg/kg bw died within 4 hr post administration.
mortality rate in females: all dead in the 112 or 200mg/kg bw. death occurred between 1 hr-4 days in the 112 mg/kg bw group and between 30 min-2 hr in the 200 mg/kg bw group. 1/10 of the animals in the 63 mg/kg bw died within 4 hr post administration.
conclusion: under the experimental conditions of this study, the LD50 was 80 mg/kg bw (71-89 mg/kg bw 95% CI), calculated for both sexes combined.
composition: test substance dissolved in distilled water
preliminary study: the dosage-range was based on a preliminary study, in which all animals (4/4) died after receiving 200 or 2000 mg/kg bw hydroxyethyl-p-phenylenediamine.

clinical examiniation in males: the animals were observed daily for 14 days for clinical abnormalities and mortality. body weights and macroscopic observations were recorded. treatment caused lethargy, piloerection, abnormal posture and reduced righting reflex for up to 6 hours after dosing.
clinical examiniation in females: the animals were observed daily for 14 days for clinical abnormalities and mortality. body weights and macroscopic observations were recorded. treatment caused lethargy, piloerection, abnormal posture and reduced righting reflex for up to 6 hours after dosing.
conclusion: ld50 was greater than 2000 mg/kg bw

clinical examiniation in males: the animals were observed daily for 14 days. bodyweights were recorded weekly and macroscopic abnormalities were recorded at autopsy. body weight gain of surviving animals was comparable to historical control data. the study authors concluded a LD50 of 2186 (1797 – 2965) mg/kg bw, with comparable toxicity in the males. clinical signs were reported in some animals of all dose groups from 30 minutes after dosing, and included: hypoactivity, sedation, piloerection and dyspnoea.  lateral decubitis was observed in one male animal. recovery was complete by day 5 for the males.
gross pathology in males: there were no macroscopic abnormalities at autopsy or in the animals found dead during the study.
clinical examiniation in females: the animals were observed daily for 14 days. bodyweights were recorded weekly and macroscopic abnormalities were recorded at autopsy. no histological examinations were performed.body weight gain of surviving animals was comparable to historical control data. the study authors concluded a LD50 of 2186 (1797 – 2965) mg/kg bw, with comparable toxicity in the males. clinical signs were reported in some animals of all dose groups from 30 minutes after dosing, and included: hypoactivity, sedation, piloerection and dyspnoea. recovery was complete by day 7 for the females.
gross pathology in females: there were no macroscopic abnormalities at autopsy or in the animals found dead during the study.
mortality rate in males: at 2000 mg/kg bw, the mortality was 60% (3/5).  all deaths occurred within 30 minutes of dosing, except for one male (day 3).
mortality rate in females: no mortalities were reported in the 1100 and 1600 mg/kg dose groups. at 2000 mg/kg bw, the mortality was 40% (2/5). four of the five females died after the dose of 2600 mg/kg bw.  all deaths occurred within 30 minutes of dosing, except for one female dosed at 2000 mg/kg bw (day 3).
conclusion: a121 was found to be moderately toxic to non-toxic via the oral route.
additional info: test substance: imexine oax in aqueous solution
dose levels unity: mg/kg bw in females; in males
limit test: groups of 5 male and 5 female rats received a single dose of test substance by gastric gavage at 2000 mg/kg bw in a limit test

clinical examiniation in males: the animals were checked daily for mortality and clinical signs. body weights were recorded at start and on days 7 and 14. no mortality or any clinical signs of systemic toxicity were recorded in the test animals. orange coloured urine was observed in all animals. body weight gain was within a normal range.
gross pathology in males: in one male, large mesenteric lymph nodes and a grey-white covering on the spleen capsule were noted
clinical examiniation in females: the animals were checked daily for mortality and clinical signs. body weights were recorded at start and on days 7 and 14. no mortality or any clinical signs of systemic toxicity were recorded in the test animals. orange coloured urine was observed in all animals. body weight gain was within a normal range.
conclusion: the acute oral LD50 in rats was greater than 2000 mg/kg bw
rodent/strain ( rat, mouse, …): rat/ him: ofa, sprague dawley, spf

clinical examiniation in males: clinical signs and mortality were checked daily for a period of 14 days following the single administration of the test item. the animals were checked for body weight gain on day 1, 8 and 15 and were subjected to necropsy. hypoactivity or sedation and piloerection were noted in all animals on day 1.  body weight gain in surviving animals was not affected by treatment with the test substance. no apparent abnormalities were observed at necropsy in all animals.
gross pathology in males: no apparent abnormalities were observed at necropsy in all animals.
clinical examiniation in females: clinical signs and mortality were checked daily for a period of 14 days following the single administration of the test item. the animals were checked for body weight gain on day 1, 8 and 15 and were subjected to necropsy. hypoactivity or sedation and piloerection were noted in all animals on day 1. lateral recumbency and tonic-clonic convulsions were also observed in two animals on day 1, one of these animals was found dead a few hours later. hypoactivity or sedation and piloerection persisted in the surviving animals up to day 3 or 4; dyspnoea and unsteady gait were recorded in the surviving females up to day 3.  body weight gain in surviving animals was not affected by treatment with the test substance.
gross pathology in females: no apparent abnormalities were observed at necropsy in all animals.
mortality rate in males: one male was found dead on day 2
mortality rate in females: two females were found dead on day 2, another female died on day 1 after a lateral recumbency and tonic-clonic convulsions
conclusion: under the experimental conditions, the LD50 of the test item was close to 1000 mg/kg bw, since a single dose of 1000 mg/kg bw induces death in 1/5 male and 3/5 female rats.
additional info: test substance: imexine oaj, test substance 2952

clinical examiniation in males: no mortality occurred. no clinical signs of toxicity were observed. the body-weight gain was not affected adversely during the study period
gross pathology in males: the macroscopic examination at terminal necropsy revealed no organ alterations
clinical examiniation in females: no mortality occurred. no clinical signs of toxicity were observed. the macroscopic examination at terminal necropsy revealed no organ alterations. the body-weight gain was not affected adversely during the study period
gross pathology in females: the macroscopic examination at terminal necropsy revealed no organ alterations
conclusion: the LD50 of the test substance administered to rats by the oral route was >2000 mg/kg bw
composition: test substance homogenised in the vehicle

clinical examiniation in males: during the observation period of 14 days, a record was kept for mortalities and signs of toxicity. body weights were recorded on day 1 and then on days 8 and 15 for the surviving animals. surviving animals showed piloerection on day 1 or until day 3 (together with dyspnea and reduce activity for the latter rat). no mortalities and no clinical signs were observed at 50 mg/kg bw. no effect on the body weight was recorded in the surviving rats given 500 mg/kg bw. at 50 mg/kg bw, a reduced body weight gain was noted in 1/5 females during the first week of the study and in 1/5 females during the second week of the study when compared to historical control animals.
gross pathology in males: all rats that died were investigated macroscopically to identify organ changes in the skull, thorax and abdomen and surviving animals were similarly examined at the end of the 14-day post-observation. at necropsy, no apparent abnormalities were observed in any animal.
mortality rate in females: at 500 mg/kg bw, 3 of the 5 female rats died on day 2. piloerection and orange-colored extremities were observed prior to death.
conclusion: moderately toxic following a single oral administration. the results of the test indicated that the maximal non-lethal oral dose was 50 mg/kg in female rats and the minimal lethal dose was 500 mg/kg bw. 500 mg/kg bw is considered close to the median lethal dose (LD50).
limit test: one female was given 500 mg/kg preceded the definitive test. hypoactivity, dyspnea and piloerection were observed from day 1 to day 3 in the animal given 500 mg/kg bw.

clinical examiniation in males: they were observed for 14 days after the day of dosing and were then killed for gross pathological examination. there were no mortalities and all animals showed the expected gain in bodyweight during the study. hunched posture and lethargy were noted in all animals on the day of dosing.
gross pathology in males: no abnormalities were noted at necropsy.
clinical examiniation in females: they were observed for 14 days after the day of dosing and were then killed for gross pathological examination. there were no mortalities and all animals showed the expected gain in bodyweight during the study. hunched posture and lethargy were noted in all animals on the day of dosing.
gross pathology in females: no abnormalities were noted at necropsy.
conclusion: ld50 of the test compound was found to be greater than 2000 mg/kg bw in rats.
composition: test material as a suspension in distilled water
additional information: a limit test. the method used followed oecd guideline n° 401 (1981), referenced as method b1 in commission cirective 84/449/eec.

clinical examiniation in males: mortality and clinical signs were checked daily for the 14-day observation period. the test substance caused dose related clinical signs to CNS, coordination, reflexes and autonomic functions increasing in severity up to 72 hours after dosing. weight gains were reduced in all surviving animals.
clinical examiniation in females: mortality and clinical signs were checked daily for the 14-day observation period. the test substance caused dose related clinical signs to CNS, coordination, reflexes and autonomic functions increasing in severity up to 72 hours after dosing. weight gains were reduced in all surviving animals.
mortality rate in males: animals died within 24-72 hours after dosing. Dose (mg/kg bw): number of dead animals, 125: 1/5, 250: 2/5, 500: 4/5, 750: 3/5, 1000: 5/5.
mortality rate in females: animals died within 24-72 hours after dosing. mortality in mice after a single oral application; dose mg/kg bx): number of dead animals, 125: 1/5, 250: 1/5, 500: 3/5, 750: 5/5, 1000: 4/5.
conclusion: lehmannblausulphat under the conditions of this study showed an LD50 of 327 mg/kg bw.
composition: test substance diluted in deionized water
SCCS comment to test: the studies are not up to modern standards but the results give an indication of the LD50 in mice.
preliminary study: a preliminary range finding test with 2 female mice of 2000 mg/kg bw indicated that the median lethal dose was less than 2000 mg/kg bw as both died within 24 hours.

clinical examiniation in males: during the first days after administration, animals of all treated groups showed decreased motor activity, squatting posture, sunken flanks, half-closed eyes, piloerection, pale skin, laboured irregular respiration, miosis and diarrhoea. all clinical signs had completely ceased by day 10.
gross pathology in males: no macroscopic alterations were observed in rats that had survived until the end of the observation period.
microscopic pathology in males: animals that had died during the study showed bleeding of the stomach mucosa, inflated stomach, white and/or partially detached stomach mucosa, hyaline aspect of the small intestine, reddened small intestinal mucosa, dark stained adrenals and lung haemorrhage
mortality rate in males: except for one male of the 1000-mg/kg bw group that was found dead on day 13, all deaths occurred within the first 5 days. at 630 mg/kg bw: not tested; 1000 mg/kg bw: 1/5; 1600 mg/kg bw: 0/5; 2500mg/kg bw: 0/5; 3150 mg/kg bw: 3/5; 4000 mg/kg bw: 5/5
mortality rate in females: except for one male of the 1000-mg/kg bw group that was found dead on day 13, all deaths occurred within the first 5 days. at 630 mg/kg bw: 1/5 ; 1000 mg/kg bw: 1/5; 1600 mg/kg bw: 2/5; 2500mg/kg bw: 4/5; 3150 mg/kg bw: not tested; 4000 mg/kg bw: not tested
conclusion: the study authors conclude that the ld50-value for Cetrimonium chloride is 2410 mg/kg day for male and female rats combined.
additional info: test substance: genamin ctac (28-30% cetrimonium chloride in water)
additional information: oecd tg 401 (1981), annex 5 to dir. 67/548/eec, method b.1: acute oral toxicity. the lowest dose only tested in females. the two highest dose only tested in males.

clinical examiniation in males: no clinical signs were observed at 2000 mg/kg neither treatment-related effects on body weight gain,
clinical examiniation in females: no clinical signs were observed at 2000 mg/kg neither treatment-related effects on body weight gain
conclusion: the study authors conclude that since no lethality occurred at 2000 mg/kg bw and no significant clinical signs were observed at this dosage level, quartamin 86w was considered to be non-toxic.
additional info: test substance: quartamin 86w (unknown percentage of steartrimonium chloride)
preliminary study: in a preliminary study with 2000 mg/kg bw one female died after 6 days.
additional information: regarding glp compliance:   only report was audited, not the study itself. oecd tg 401, annex 5 to dir. 67/548/eec, method b.1: acute oral toxicity

clinical examiniation in males: the following clinical signs occurred at all dose levels during the first days after administration: squatting posture, sunken flanks, bristled coat, stilted and uncoordinated gait, half-closed eyes, irregular respiration, swollen abdomen, and diarrhoea. additionally, ataxia was observed in animals of the 2000 mg/kg bw group. all symptoms had completely disappeared by day 8. body weight development was not impaired.
microscopic pathology in males: animals that had died during the study showed inflated stomach, detachment of the stomach mucosa and petechial bleedings, small intestinal containing yellowish mucous or clear fluid, detachment of intestinal mucosa, mucosal bleeding. no macroscopic alterations were observed in rats that survived until the end of the observation period.
clinical examiniation in females: the following clinical signs occurred at all dose levels during the first days after administration: squatting posture, sunken flanks, bristled coat, stilted and uncoordinated gait, half-closed eyes, irregular respiration, swollen abdomen, and diarrhoea. additionally, ataxia was observed in animals of the 2000 mg/kg bw group. all symptoms had completely disappeared by day 8. body weight development was not impaired.
microscopic pathology in females: animals that had died during the study showed inflated stomach, detachment of the stomach mucosa and petechial bleedings, small intestinal containing yellowish mucous or clear fluid, detachment of intestinal mucosa, mucosal bleeding. no macroscopic alterations were observed in rats that survived until the end of the observation period.
mortality rate in males: except for one male and one female that were found dead on days 4 and 7, respectively, all deaths occurred within the first day. at 630 mg/kg bw: not tested, at 800mg/kg bw: 0/5, at 1250 mg/kg bw: not tested, at 2000 mg/kg bw: 5/5
mortality rate in females: except for one male and one female that were found dead on days 4 and 7, respectively, all deaths occurred within the first day. at 630 mg/kg bw: 2/5, at 800mg/kg bw: 3/5, at 1250 mg/kg bw: 5/5, at 2000 mg/kg bw: 5/5
conclusion: the study authors calculated a ld50 value of 702.5 mg/kg bw for female rats using the probit method, whereas the ld50 value in males could not be calculated.
additional info: test substance: genamin stac (79.2% steartrimonium chloride, 19.1% isopropanol and 0.9% water)
additional information: only 800 and 2000mg /kg bw tested in males. regarding glp compliance:   only report was audited, not the study itself. oecd tg 401, annex 5 to dir. 67/548/eec, method b.1: acute oral toxicity

clinical examiniation in males: clinical signs: piloerection, breathing difficulties, staining of fur, urine and faeces.
clinical examiniation in females: clinical signs: piloerection, breathing difficulties, staining of fur, urine and faeces.
mortality rate in males: 3 males died within 5 days of dosing.
conclusion: the oral ld50 in rats exceeded 2000 mg/kg bw.

clinical examiniation in males: clinical signs at 2000 mg/kg bw: piloerection, reduced activity, hunched posture, breathing difficulties, staining of fur, urine and faeces, swollen abdomen.
clinical examiniation in females: clinical signs at 2000 mg/kg bw: piloerection, reduced activity, hunched posture, breathing difficulties, staining of fur, urine and faeces, swollen abdomen.
mortality rate in males: at 2000 mg/kg bw, 1 male died within 48 hours of dosing. No mortalities at lower dose levels.
mortality rate in females: at 2000 mg/kg bw, 1 female died within 48 hours of dosing. no mortalities at lower dose levels.
conclusion: the oral ld50 in rats exceeded 2000 mg/kg bw.

clinical examiniation in males: signs of reaction to treatment observed shortly after dosing in all rats were increased salivation, pilo-erection, hunched posture and abnormal gait (waddling). recovery was complete by day 3.
clinical examiniation in females: signs of reaction to treatment observed shortly after dosing in all rats were increased salivation, pilo-erection, hunched posture and abnormal gait (waddling). recovery was complete by day 3.
conclusion: the acute lethal oral dose to rats of arianor straw yellow was greater than 2.0 g/kg bw.

clinical examiniation in males: signs of reactions to treatment were observed shortly after dosing in all surviving animals, including lethargy, red discolorations of urine and red teguments. males treated at 316 mg/kg bw showed a statistically significant delay of body weight gain from day 8 onwards. recovery of survivors, as judged by external appearance and behaviour, was apparently complete within 4 days of treatment. no macroscopic findings that could be associated with treatment were observed on rats sacrificed on study termination.
gross pathology in males: autopsy of the rats found dead during the study revealed discoloration of the stomach with black areas, marked dilatation of the bladder by a black liquid, pale white to dark red areas in the liver.
clinical examiniation in females: signs of reactions to treatment were observed shortly after dosing in all surviving animals, including lethargy, red discolorations of urine and red teguments. no body weight changes comparing to control rats were noted in the low dose group and in the females from the medium dose group. recovery of survivors, as judged by external appearance and behaviour, was apparently complete within 4 days of treatment. no macroscopic findings that could be associated with treatment were observed on rats sacrificed on study termination.
gross pathology in females: autopsy of the rats found dead during the study revealed discoloration of the stomach with black areas, marked dilatation of the bladder by a black liquid, pale white to dark red areas in the liver.
mortality rate in males: at the dose level of 501 mg/kg bw, 3 males  were found dead on day 2, one additional male was found dead on day 3.
mortality rate in females: one female was found dead 15 minutes after treatment at the dose of 316 mg/kg bw. at the dose level of 501 mg/kg bw,one female was found dead on day 2. four additional females were found dead on day 3.
conclusion: the acute median lethal oral dose (ld50) to rats of hc red n°16 was calculated to be around 392 mg/kg. hc red n°16 should then be considered as harmful when administered by the oral route.
composition: test substance in 1% aqueous dispersion of cacmc in deionised water
vehicle name: aqueous dispersion of carboxymethylcellulose in deionised water

clinical examiniation in males: no clinical abnormalities were observed. weight gain of the animals was what would be expected of this strain.
gross pathology in males: no abnormalities were found at autopsy.
clinical examiniation in females: no clinical abnormalities were observed. weight gain of the animals was what would be expected of this strain.
gross pathology in females: no abnormalities were found at autopsy.
composition: suspension of the test substance in the vehicle
housing and feeding: animals  had been fasted for 17 hours
own comments: the oecd guideline is not mentioned in the opinion. however, it's clearly stated that the study is done in accordance with oecd guidelines. considering the design of the study, it should have been done under oecd 401

clinical examiniation in males: no clinical signs were observed during the study.
microscopic pathology in males: microscopic examination of the main organs of the animals revealed no apparent abnormalities. no histopathological examination was performed
clinical examiniation in females: no clinical signs were observed during the study.
microscopic pathology in females: microscopic examination of the main organs of the animals revealed no apparent abnormalities. no histopathological examination was performed
SCCS comment to test: animals were observed until day 8 instead of for 14 days, but since no mortality was registered, it can be deduced that the oral ld50 is higher than 500 mg/kg b.w

clinical examiniation in males: yellow colorations of the skin and mucosae were observed until the fourth day after administration of the tested dose. no other signs of reaction to treatment were observed.
clinical examiniation in females: yellow colorations of the skin and mucosae were observed until the fourth day after administration of the tested dose. no other signs of reaction to treatment were observed.
conclusion: the results of the test indicated that the lethal oral dose (ld50), was above 5 g/kg bw
composition: aqueous suspension of test substance in the vehicle
limit test: hc yellow n°4 was prepared as a 50 % suspension in distilled water and administered by oral intubation at the doses of 1, 2.5 and 5 g/kg bw in range finding test (2 males per dose). as no mortalities occurred at these doses, 5 g/kg bw was chosen for the primary test (5 males and 5 females).

clinical examiniation in males: no effects on body weight and body weight gain were observed. all animals showed signs of malaise (e.g. decreased motor activity, ruffled fur, closed eyes, hunched posture, decreased muscular tension or unconsciousness). in some animals ataxia, dyspnoea or low grade convulsions were observed. effects diminished and returned to normal within 6hr – 1wk post administration.
gross pathology in males: 7/20 of the animals that died early did not show any clinical signs at the post-mortem examination. most of the other animals that died early showed signs of shock due to severe gastrointestinal irritations or hepatotoxicity
clinical examiniation in females: no effects on body weight and body weight gain were observed. all animals showed signs of malaise (e.g. decreased motor activity, ruffled fur, closed eyes, hunched posture, decreased muscular tension or unconsciousness). in some animals ataxia, dyspnoea or low grade convulsions were observed. effects diminished and returned to normal within 6hr – 1wk post administration.
gross pathology in females: 7/20 of the animals that died early did not show any clinical signs at the post-mortem examination. most of the other animals that died early showed signs of shock due to severe gastrointestinal irritations or hepatotoxicity
mortality rate in males: all dead in the 112 or 200mg/kg bw. death occurred between 1 hr-4 days in the 112 mg/kg bw group and between 30 min-2 hr in the 200 mg/kg bw group. 1/10 of the animals in the 63 mg/kg bw died within 4 hr post administration.
mortality rate in females: all dead in the 112 or 200mg/kg bw. death occurred between 1 hr-4 days in the 112 mg/kg bw group and between 30 min-2 hr in the 200 mg/kg bw group. 1/10 of the animals in the 63 mg/kg bw died within 4 hr post administration.
conclusion: under the experimental conditions of this study, the LD50 was 80 mg/kg bw (71-89 mg/kg bw 95% CI), calculated for both sexes combined.
composition: test substance dissolved in the veicle
preliminary study: the dosage-range was based on a preliminary study, in which all animals (4/4) died after receiving 200 or 2000 mg/kg bw hydroxyethyl-p-phenylenediamine.
